Hace 20 años migró de su natal Andahuaylas para establecerse en la ciudad de Lima, donde viene trabajando incansablemente por un futuro mejor para su familia. Felizmente tiene una buena cantidad de clientela, pero las cosas no son fáciles, ya que para dejar los acabados como se necesitan debe tener las herramientas necesarias, de las cuales carece. A futuro, Visitación quiere tener una tienda donde pueda vender gas, ya que es un negocio muy lucrativo. Hace 4 años que trabaja con MFP y siempre le ha ido muy bien, este es su segundo préstamo individual y es puntual en sus pagos. El dinero solicitado será para la compra de algunas herramientas que le facilitarán su trabajo como albañil.
texts.en:
Vicitación is 43 years old, and is originally from the city of Andahuaylas. He lives with his wife Catalina, who is 43, and their son Andy, 9. Their other children are independent. For 18 years, he has been in the business of bricklaying; his uncle taught him all the techniques he needs to do high-quality work that leaves all his clients satisfied. Twenty years ago he moved from his native Andahuaylas to live in the city of Lima, where he has been working tirelessly to make a better future for his family.

Fortunately, he has a large number of clients, but things are not easy because he lacks the necessary tools in order to properly finish his jobs. In the future, Vicitación wants to have a store where he can sell gas, which is a lucrative business.

He has been working with MFP for four years, and it has always gone well. This is his second individual loan, and he is punctual with his payments. The money he requested will be used to buy some tools that will help his work as a mason.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Iverson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es: Marlene tiene 34 años, vive con su pareja que se dedica a la venta de combustible, es madre de 4 hijos, 2 de ellos estudian y 2 ya culminaron sus estudios y por el momento la apoyan en su negocio. Desde hace 16 años se dedica a la venta de comida por las mañanas, vende en la parte de afuera de su vivienda bajo una pequeña ramada (techo de madera y paja) construida por su pareja. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que muchas personas degusten de su buena sazón y darles una buena atención a sus clientes es lo primordial para ella. La dificultad es no contar con un local apropiado para su negocio, sin embargo le es muy rentable porque se encuentra ubicado en una zona comercial y sus ganancias son diarias. Su propósito a futuro, es llegar a tener un restaurante. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP y espera desenvolverse muy bien con su grupo porque ha observado la responsabilidad y compañerismo que hay entre todos, lo que considera muy bueno. Con el dinero que solicita comprará mesas, sillas y utensilios de cocina.
texts.en:
Marlene is 34 years old and the mother of 4 children. Two of her children are still students while the other two completed their studies and are now helping her with the business. Her partner is a fuel salesman. For 16 years, she has been selling food every morning. Her business is situated outside of her home under an arbor (made of wood and has a straw roof) built by her husband. What she likes most about her job is coming into contact with many people, and she believes providing good service to her customers is extremely important. Her main difficulty is that she does not have enough room for her business. She still makes good profits because she is located in a commercial area and her earnings are generated on a daily basis. In the future, Marlene would like to own a restaurant.

This is her first loan with MFP and she hopes to get along well with her communal bank group. She has observed their responsibility and the camaraderie among all the members, so she feels very good about this decision. With the money she is requesting, she will purchase tables, chairs and cooking utensils.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tables, chairs and cooking utensils for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aquilino

texts.en:
Aquilino A. is from the town of Southwestern CalA. Mis. Occ. He is 47-years old. Aquilino is married and has five school-aged children. He owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fried foods in the local community. Aquilino has been engaged in his business for over five years.

In 2006, Aquilino joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aquilino has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. He is requesting a new loan to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Aquilino from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay school tuition fees for his children. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Emie

texts.en:
Emie B. is from the village of Sulipat, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 27-years old. Emie is married and has two school-aged children. TEmie owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing  transport services to local community members. Emie has been engaged in her business for over two years.

In 2009, Emie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. Emie is requesting a new loan to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Emie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase a transport vehicle

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia J. is from the village of Bunawan, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Nelia is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Nelia owns & operates a business buying and selling wood coco lumber. Nelia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (about $208 US) a month for these activities.

In 2006, Nelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelia has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 25,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional wood products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Nelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (about $146 US) a month from these activities.

Elsa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 pesos from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Elsa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Morn

texts.en: Mr. Morn M. is married and the father of six children, three of whom are married and live independently, while the other three are still living in the family home.  All of his three single children are employed in different occupations.  His wife stays at home and is responsible for the daily housework. She also assists him on the farm. Because the annual farming business has been the main way to earn a living since Morn M.’s grandparents were alive, he was encouraged to continue doing it.  Besides his farm work, he also buys cows to raise their offspring for sale. Morn M. faces hardship in transportation because he doesn't own a vehicle.  He needs his own transportation.  Morn M. will use his loan to buy a new motor that he will use to better support his ox-trade activity. Note: The woman who appears in the photograph above is Morn M.’s wife.

loans.use: To buy a new motor that he will use to better support his ox-trade activity

loans.name: Cherry Lou

texts.en:
Cherry Lou D. is from the town of Sinian, Baliangao Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Cherry Lou is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Cherry Lou owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Cherry Lou has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (about $104 US) a month for these activities.

In 2008, Cherry Lou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cherry Lou has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Cherry Lou is requesting a new loan of 2,000 pesos which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & bamboo. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Cherry Lou from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Annabel

texts.en:
Annabel D. is from the village of Lantay Valencia Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Annabel is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Annabel owns & operates a business making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling banana chips and other delicacies in the local community. Annabel is just starting this business.

In 2009, Annabel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annabel is requesting a loan of 5,000 pesos which will be used to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Annabel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Griva

texts.en:
Griva E. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 55 years old. Griva is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Griva owns and operates a business that provides motorcycle-for-hire services to local community members. Griva is just starting this business.

In 2006, Griva joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Griva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. Griva is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase a cab to attach to her motorcycle to improve the business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Griva from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase side car for the motorcycle for hire

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en:
Adelfa B. is from the village of Lilo-an, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old. Adelfa is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Adelfa owns and operates a sari-sari (general store). She sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste etc., in the local community. Adelfa has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Adelfa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelfa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Adelfa from GDMPC. She plans to save the additional revenue generated from the business as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine C. is from the village of Lantay Valencia Bukidnon. She is 51 years old. Josephine is widowed and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells a variety of different products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and to finance the family's basic needs. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en: Sreng B. is a married father 40 years in age. He works in the village committee as a consultant adviser. In addition, he and his wife have always cultivated a rice crop during the growing season. This couple lives with their three school-aged children in the rural area of Phnom Penh Town. Sreng B. is taking out a loan to combine with his personal savings to buy a small plot of land that he will grow rice on it. He purposes to earn extra income by hiring the half of land that he bought to other farmer in the village.

loans.use: To buy a small plot of land that he will grow rice on it

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ronelyn

texts.en:
Ronelyn J. is from the village of Lantay, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Ronelyn is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Ronelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells a variety of different products in the local community. Ronelyn has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene C. is from the village of Montela, Aurora. She is 36 years old. Arlene is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Arlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Arlene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rin

texts.en: Rin V. is 35-year-old farmer and married woman. During the morning and in the late afternoon she works with her farming tools in the field. She normally grows cabbages, cucumbers, and morning glories from her own farmland that was inherited from her grandmother years ago. She will sell her crop when it matures, every two months after she begins planting.  Her husband helps her in the field. Rin V. dreams of having a moto to use for her family’s traveling needs but she does not enough money to buy it. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $700 to buy a motorcycle. This moto will help her to cut costs by no longer hiring taxis.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Eoum

texts.en: Eoum Y., age 35, has worked for a local garment factory in Takeo Province since 2003. Typically, she makes $2 US per day. Y. and her husband work very hard all day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for their family. They are blessed to have a four-month-old child. Y.'s husband is a motor-taxi driver who makes approximately $3 US per day by providing transportation services to local people. Y. wants to take out a loan of $800 US to purchase a new motorbike for her husband, as his current bike is in bad condition and consumes too much gasoline because of its age. She hopes that a new motorbike will allow her husband to work more and thus generate more income for their family. This picture features Y.'s husband, as she was not available at the time it was taken.

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike

loans.name: Seoun

texts.en: Seuon P., age 29, works in the agriculture sector as a rice farmer, making a typical income of $1 US per day. P. and her husband work hard to ensure that they and their two young children, who are not yet old enough to be enrolled in school, can live comfortably. Her husband travels from place to place in his province selling carpets and bedroom materials. He makes approximately $5 US per day. P. wants to take out a loan of $1,000 US so that her husband can expand his business's inventory in the hopes of generating more income for her household expenses and their childrens' future education. P.'s husband is featured in this picture.

loans.use: Purchasing carpets to increase business inventory

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch Y. is a 57-year-old married woman living on a low income in the province of Kompong Chhnang.  She sells a few grocery items from her home to help earn a living. For over a year now she has been selling her items to the neighbors and is earning approximately $2 each day toward meeting the needs of her family. Her husband is responsible and supports the family by selling baskets. He buys baskets in bulk on credit from his suppliers and resells them outside of his home to earn a profit. This couple has been blessed with six children, four who are now married and live away from home and the other two are still single and in school. Most of their children also assist with their business activities. Touch Y. is requesting a loan so her husband can buy a large quantity of baskets to sell.  He is shown in the photo above.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of baskets to sell.

loans.name: Meng

texts.en: Meng P., age 30, works in the weaving business, typically making $3 US per day. In Cambodia, the traditional method of weaving requires hard work and time to produce the best outputs that will receive competitive prices at the market. P. and her husband work hard to ensure that their family, including a seven-year-old child attending a local primary school, can live comfortably. Meng's husband works at home selling vegetables and snacks from their house, and, like Meng, makes around $3 US per day. Meng wants to take out a loan for $800 US so that her husband can expand his shop's inventory by buying rice and other goods. They plan to use the money for general household expenses and saving for their child's future education.

loans.use: Purchasing rice and other goods to sell in a home-based shop

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en:
Leonor is 61 years old and married to Joaquin, a tricycle driver, in the beautiful Antique province town of Hamtic. She has five grown children and has supported them over the years through various farming activities and through her husband's business.

This loan of 14,000 Pesos is for hog fattening, a popular business for people in poverty where she is from. She will buy four small piglets, three racks of feed and vitamins for the piglets with her loan. She will then grow them for approximately six months until they are ready for market.

It is her dream to be a successful businesswoman and she believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed and also be able to help her family rise out of poverty.

-Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: To buy piglets, feed and vitamins

loans.name: Ut

texts.en: Ut S., 39, has been involved in agriculture as a farmer growing vegetables with a typical income of US $2 per day. S. and her husband work so hard all days to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. S. and her husband are blessed with five children; three of them have attended a local school, and the rest are employed as garment factory workers. Her husband is a rice field farmer too who usually earn around US $2 per day. S. really wants to take a loan of US $500 to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her cultivation. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to produce more output to sell at the markets for a better income to cover her family expenses as well as for saving to support her children’s future education. (Her husband is presented in the picture)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Kem

texts.en: Kem Y., 45, has been involved in the grocery business with a typical income of US $3 per day. Y. and her husband work so hard all days to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. Y. and her husband are blessed with four school-aged children who have all attended a local school. Her husband is a local government schoolteacher with a typical income of approximately US $2 per day. Y. really wants to take a loan of US $500 to expand her inventory by purchasing more groceries for her store at home to generate more income for her household expenses and save for her children’s future education.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is a 65-year-old widow living in the beautiful green farm country of the Antique province town of Hamtic. She has two grown children, one of whom is a nurse, while the other is in information technology. Over the years she has provided for her family by operating a variety of businesses including farming and operating a sari sari store (general store) in her village.

This loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (or about $225 US) is for hog fattening, a popular business for people in her area suffering from poverty. She will buy four small piglets, two sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will also construct a small nipa hut (a hut made of a kind of palm) for her pigs to live in. She will raise them for approximately six months until they are ready for sale.

It is her dream to be a successful businesswoman. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of poverty.

Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: Hog fattening

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
S. owns old handicraft equipment that she uses to weave baskets for her husband to sell outside of their home. She typically makes around 10 sets of baskets a day which sell at about $0.50 per basket. She saves up to at least 100 sets of baskets to sell at a time. In addition, S. always takes time to cultivate a rice crop.

S. is a 30-year-old living in Kampong Chhnang Province. She has been blessed with four school-age children. She is applying for a loan to be used to buy a cow to help plow her farmland.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando F. owns and manages a sari-sari store (a kind of general store) in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. His wife has died and now it is only he who takes care of their six children. He formerly worked as a security guard, but, because the compensation is low, he decided to quit and open his sari-sari store.

In 1995, he started selling different goods. His profit enabled him to buy a parcel of rice farm to generate additional income.

Now, he needs additional capital to grow his business. He wants to use this loan to buy additional groceries and increase his income.

He chose CEVI for its wide services. CEVI gives him credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: to purchase assorted groceries

loans.name: Nub

texts.en: Nub K., 31, produces doormats in the province of Takeo. She typically generates an income of $2.60 US per day. K. and her husband work hard daily to ensure a comfortable standard of living for their family. K. and her husband are blessed with two young children who have not attended school yet. Her husband is employed as a driver for a private company and earns around $5 per day. K. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase fabrics and silk to produce more doormats and silk scarves. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to increase her output to generate more income so she can cover her family expenses. She also wants to save money so she can pay for her children’s future education.

loans.use: purchasing fabrics and silk

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia A. manages a medium-sized store. She has been in this business since 1996. So far, her business is doing well. Because of her business, she was able to buy a rice farm, which is 3 hectares in size. She was also able to send her two children in school.
 
Cecilia wants to make her business grow more. She is requesting a loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (or about $525 US) to purchase assorted merchandise for her store. She thinks that the loan will help attract more customers, which will also help increase her family's income.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides loans, training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase assorted merchandise for her store

loans.name: Kheoun

texts.en: KH. H., 27, operates a sewing business that generates a typical income of $2.60 US per day in the province of Takeo. H. and her husband work hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for their family. H. and her husband are blessed with two young children who have not yet attended school. Her husband is a shoemaker who operates from their house and usually earns around $13.30 per day. H. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase animal skins to produce more shoes for her husband's customers. By doing this, she hopes that her husband will be able to produce more goods to sell at markets to increase their income. They will then be able to cover their family expenses and save to support her children’s future education.

loans.use: Purchasing animal skins for shoes.

loans.name: Nonita

texts.en:
Nonita is a 47-year-old woman who lives with her husband Constrado, a laborer, and their seven children in the beautiful green farm country of the Antique province town of Hamtic. She currently has a small business buying and selling bananas and charcoal to her neighbors but it's hard to save enough to make the business grow and be more profitable. 

This loan of 6,000 Pesos as additional capital would offer her the opportunity to buy those goods in bulk for less money, make more profit and help her family rise out of poverty.

It is her dream to be a successful businesswoman and she believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed and be able to help her family rise out of poverty. Her greatest wish is to be able to afford a concrete house for her family; currently they live in a bamboo hut. Where they are there are a lot of typhoons every year and it's dangerous because their house is not very stable. She also would like to be able to start saving to send her children to college. 

Written by Sloane Berrent, Kiva Fellow

loans.use: To buy her products in bulk

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Phon S., 31, has been involved in a business of selling beverages and raising livestock at home with a typical income of US $2.6 per day in Takeo Province since 2000. S. works so hard all days to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. S. is a widow. She is blessed with two young children who have been enrolled in a local primary school. S. really wants to take a loan of US $1000 to expand her inventory by purchasing various kinds of beverages for her store. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as to save to support her children’s future education.

loans.use: To purchase more soft drinks

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn F.'s business is direct selling. She started it in 1985. She is still doing the same thing because she earns a bigger income in this kind of business. She buys merchandise like home decor, stuffed toys, herbal medicines and sells it to her network of contacts. She is 46 years old and has four kids. She wants to make her business even better to be able to help her husband send their children to school.

She needs additional capital for her business.  She is asking for a loan of PH 25,000 to purchase various merchandise that she can sell. In that way, she believes that she can contribute also to the family income.

Now, she avails the services of Community Economic Venture Inc. She has loans, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to sell

loans.name: Mei

texts.en:
Mei P., 60, has been involved in a business of producing door mats with a typical income of US $1.30 per day in Takeo Province since 2000. P. and her husband work very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family.

P. and her husband are blessed with three children; two of them are enrolled in a local high school, and another one is employed in a garment factory. Her husband operates a business on his own as a door mat seller who has to travel long distances in his province and other nearby places to sell his products. He usually earns around US $9 per day.

P. really wants to take a loan of US $1000 to purchase more door mats for husband to expand his inventory to sell to his customers. By doing this, she hopes that her husband will be able to generate a better income to cover her family's expenses as well as to save to cover her children’s future education.

loans.use: purchasing door mats

loans.name: Chab

texts.en:
Chab K., 43, has been involved in a business of selling groceries at home with a typical income of US $4.20 per day in Takeo Province since 1998. K. works very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. She and her husband are blessed with five children; two of them are students at a local high school, and the rest are employed with a fair income to earn a living. Her husband is a palm sugar seller who usually generates a gross income of US $33 in revenue per day.

K. really wants to take a loan of US $1000 to expand her inventory by purchasing more various kinds of groceries for her store. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as to save to cover her children’s future education.

loans.use: purchasing more groceries for resale

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep S., 50, has been involved in a business of selling fish and vegetables with a gross income of US $21 per day in Takeo Province since 1995. S. works very hard every day to ensure a comfortable standard of living for the family. S. and her husband are blessed with a young child who is enrolled in a local primary school. Her husband is a motor taxi driver with a typical income of US $7 per day.

S. really wants to take a loan of US $1000 to purchase a new motorbike for husband since his old motorbike is gasoline-hungry and usually gets broken. With any remainder, she wants to expand her inventory by purchasing more vegetables and fish. By doing this, she hopes that she will be able to generate a better income to cover her family expenses as well as for savings to support her child’s future education.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike, vegetables, and fish
